title: Tutorchain.io - On chain reviews
description: Finding an expert or monetizing your expertise requires centralized vetting services that limit your choices and control your access.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal seems like a great idea to use metadata based on actual monetary transactions to build reputations, focused initially in the academic tutoring space. Its not clear from the proposal, are you expecting transactions to happen on chain in ADA? It should be noted the proposers have submitted a basically the same idea into 5 other challenges, though it fits reasonably well here.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposers have outlined a relatively simple plan to get a minimal viable product up and running and have both the technical and domain expertise to get this going. It would be nice to see a little more about their plans to scale the project past the initial trial phase. Are they always going to need initial high cost vetting of tutors, or is there a way to decentralise this? Do they have ideas on how to make the ratings system objective rather than subjective? Ie based on outcomes of students? If rolled out at scale how do you stop tutors cheating and self dealing with themselves in round trip transactions then reviewing themselves? As the same proposal has been submitted 6 times with different budgets, I am not sure what they actually need to finance this.
f6_assessments.q2: This is a relatively simple proposal to deveop an MVP and as such clear milestones for progress have been presented. It would be nice to have some goals on the 6 and 12 moth timeline against which success is measured. How many tutors/students is successful (10,100,1000?). How much value through the market place.?

f6_assessments.q0: The project clearly defines the problem of a suitable, international platform for tutoring services. These services are costly and/or lack functionality. It uses a combination of tradiitional web and the blockchain. The blockchain is used for payments and authenticity (of reviewing). Both usages for the blockchain are the stronghand of the technology. It's sets a good example of how traditional development and blockchain can work together. As such it will promote the usage of blockchains. To that also contributes that the first target audience is academic stem scientist, who will appreciate the most peer reviewed blockchain cardano.
f6_assessments.q1: The project has already been worked on and has a clearl defined timeline with realistic goals. The budget and plan is sensible. The team consists of a developer and a scientist. A frontend developer will be added to the team once the stage for frontend development has arrived. The problem of the initial getgo (when trust in platform is missing) is well reflected and will be solved by networking of the scientist and scaling down the initial audience for academic tutoring in a specialized field.
f6_assessments.q2:
Roadmap and milestones are defined and reasonable. it depends a bit on future cardano development (plautus) but i wouldn't regard that as a risk. More as an asset.
The definition of success is clearly defined in the roadmap. 
The problems/challenges, and risks and their solutions to it are described in an exemplary way. 
As a note i want to add that the amount of the requested funding for such a good project and exemplary proposal is comparably humble.

f6_assessments.q0:
There are some missed opportunities with these duplicate proposals involving Tutorchain.io. In this regard, right from the beginning, the solution description talks about smart contracts...but not transaction metadata. This project very well could involve metadata, and parts of this project made open source and then those parts shared to explain how metadata can be used...and then this proposal could have been made as a segment of the larger project that would address that metadata challenge.
So, some modification of these proposals, and perhaps going for smaller dollar amounts in more challenges: is a future route to consider.
f6_assessments.q1: I think the plans and experience of this team is good enough to produce a proof-of-concept for their app, but that the correct proposal needs selecting for their project.
f6_assessments.q2: I think the information provided is in depth and covers many of the needed aspects of then needing to plan a project using that information. However, I just believe the correct proposal needs selecting that is appropriate to its associated campaign.

f6_assessments.q0: this proposal has the potential to be a real catalyst to Project Catalyst itself. Building an app where tutors and students can connect directly without the help of an intermediate would indeed greatly benefit the education system. Using the metadata of smart contracts on your app to store the reviews is a perfect example of what this challenge represents. I fully agree that this proposal addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1: The experience from the proposers gives you the feeling that they are well equipped for the job. They have an extensive background of accomplished projects in the non-crypto area. The time schedule given seems like a tight schedule for the proposal but is surely doable. They state that they need extra team members for the job which is a good sign, but it would've been better if they said exact numbers on how many people would be needed. One thing that is missing in the proposal is a clear breakdown of what the budget is needed for. It's needed for testing and prototyping but it would've been helpful to see if they are hiring 1 or 2 people for testing the app and what the hourly rate would be.
f6_assessments.q2: The roadmap/timeline presented contributes to a clear view on timestamps in the proposal where the team can look upon or push towards to. Reading the proposal and the other proposals requested by the proposers gives a feeling that they clearly understand the challenge and problem they address. One element that is missing for me is risk management. Since the proposal stretches over different challenges, what happens if one proposal doesn't get funded? Since the funding is requested for testing what happens if a major flaw is detected that isn't within budget? Seeing all the information that is within the proposal I have confidence that it's enough to assess the development of this proposal.

solution: Use smart contracts to store customer reviews that are verifiably associated with monetary exchange. Experts build reputations they control.
experience: Founders are a software engineer (crypto startup experience) and a physics professor—skills and connections to capture the tutoring market.
